text: Discretion is for case by case, it’s not for deciding not to enforce laws.  Would you be ok if Ken Cuccinelli used discretion to not enforce all hate crime laws?
author: notlarrysabato

text: that's slightly different because he's deciding what decisions to appeal and what laws he can still defend.  I think the AG decided to stop defending Marshall/Newman because of court cases that made it clear they would lose if they did so, and waste taxpayer dollars in process.
author: notlarrysabato

text: Much prefer this to the absurdity of people running for prosecutor positions who just say they won't enforce the laws they don't like.  That only leads to chaos in the system- and do we really want Trump style prosecutors deciding which laws they will enforce? Nope.  (2/2)
author: notlarrysabato

text: Governors and Presidents have the power to do this, in fact they have a duty to do so if they believe it to be the right thing as it is a constitutional responsibility with the pardon and commuting powers given to an executive.  (1/2)
author: notlarrysabato

text: I suggest reading some of the reports from gun safety groups on the problems with the background check system that need to be corrected.
author: notlarrysabato

text: Sort of.  If the background check showed that, yes it would reject.  But the system is messed up with many shared names- and does not require SSN's, so the net result is it does not pick up on that in many (most?) cases.
author: notlarrysabato

text: I don't agree with what you think is in there apparently.
author: notlarrysabato

text: police are always notified when someone fails a background check, its part of the system.
author: notlarrysabato

text: that's not correct.
author: notlarrysabato

text: right, because democrats didn't put anything in the bill to deal with that to begin with.  So then you ended up with a republican asshole amendment to notify ICE instead of local police.
author: notlarrysabato

text: sure, but making people walk that plank of a vote is crazy.
author: notlarrysabato

text: If our position is everyone who buys a gun should get a background check (supported by about 90% of the public)- then no one should be able to get a gun instantly that isn't in the background check system. Most obvious statement ever- but somehow that is controversial?
author: notlarrysabato

text: Part of the citizenship (or green card) process is a background check, but if someone is undocumented then any history that would prevent them from buying a gun from their country of citizenship would not be available.
author: notlarrysabato

text: How does Democratic leadership let a bill go to the floor that doesn't prevent people who aren't in the federal background check system from purchasing a gun?
author: notlarrysabato
